The motion and transport of nanoparticles in the brain cortex will be examined experimentally and analytically. Two-photon excited fluorescence (2PEF) microscopy will be used to visualize and track in real time the motion of nanoparticles infused directly into the cortex of live, anesthetized rats. Recent evidence suggests that nanoparticles travel rapidly along perivascular spaces -- thin annular regions surrounding cortical blood vessels -- and may be propelled through perivascular spaces by heartbeat-driven pulsations of blood vessel walls. The project comprises three approaches. First, 2PEF microscopy will be used to measure the velocities of infused nanoparticles inside the perivascular space and outside the perivascular space in the rat cortex. Effects of particle size and heartbeat rate on these velocities will be determined, and comparisons will be made between rigid nanoparticles and deformable liposomes. Second, the motion of nanoparticles will be studied in vitro in thin neural tissue slices to provide data that support and extend the in vivo measurements. Third, an analysis of the hydrodynamics in the perivascular space will be carried out to help interpret data and examine effects that are difficult to test experimentally.
Many new therapeutic compounds that have been developed in recent years to treat serious brain disorders, including cancer, are difficult to deliver to brain tissue. Most drugs administered intravenously are prevented from entering brain tissue by the blood-brain barrier. Convection-enhanced delivery (CED) is an innovative method that circumvents the blood-brain barrier by infusing drugs and drug-laden nanoparticles through a fine needle or catheter that is inserted into the brain through a small hole in the skull. Although the method is promising, it has proven difficult in practice to predict the spatial distribution of infused drugs and nanoparticles or to guarantee that they reach targeted tissue. For example, in CED therapy for brain gliomas, the most prevalent form of brain cancer, the drugs often do not penetrate far enough into the brain to reach malignant cells that readily infiltrate healthy tissue. To optimize CED therapy, it is essential to understand the fundamental mechanisms of nanoparticle transport in brain tissue. The experiments and analysis carried out in this project will provide results that researchers and clinicians can use in planning CED strategies and that scientists and engineers can use in developing computer-based models to predict the distribution of infused drugs throughout the brain.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to understand how extremely small particles are transported when they are injected into the brain. This detailed view of how small particles move through brain tissue when infused under pressure is critical for the optimization of modern therapeutics for brain diseases. Small particles, ranging from tens to hundreds of nanometers in diameter, can be decorated with molecules that cause them to bind to specifically targeted cells and can carry complex therapeutics inside them, potentially enabling more targeted and effectivce therapies. Such particles do not effectively cross from the blood into the brain, so they must be delivered directly into the brain tissue. For example, after surgically removing a brain tumor, it would be possible to infuse nanoparticles that target any remaining cancer cells and deliver a drug that killed them, decreasing the probability of tumor reoccurrence. For such an approach to work, however, it is necessary to understand how these small particles make their way through the brain tissue. 

In this work, we used optical imaging techniques to directly follow how injected nanoparticles moved through the brain of rats. The accompanying image shows and example of the kind of data we collected. Blood vessels are shown in green and the cloud of injected nanoparticles is shown in red. The image frames areabout half a millimeter in size and show how things change in time from before starting the injection (left) to 3 minutes (middle) and 5 minutes (right) after starting the injection. This injection was for particles that were 40 nanometers in diameter and were somewhat flexible. The spread of the nanoparticles through the brain tissue and along some blood vessels is evident. From data like this, we identified a several critical features of nanoparticle transport in the brain. We found that the spaces just outside blood vessels -- called perivascular spaces -- have a lower resistance to nanoparticle movement than the bulk brain tissue. For very small particles (< 50 nanometers in diameter), the transport speed in the perivascular space was about ten times faster than in the bulk brain tissue. For larger particles (>100 nanometers in diameter), there was virtually no transport in the bulk brain tissue and only perivascular transport was important. 

These results could have important implications for the treatment of brain disease with nanoparticle-based targeted therapies. For example, in the case of glioblastoma, a severe kind of brain cancer, studies have shown that tumor cells that invade the tissue surrounding the primary tumor mass tend to migrate along and stay near the ouside of blood vessels, in the perivascular space. After a surgical resection of the bulk of the tumor, these cells that have invaded the surrounding tissue lead to a reoccurance of the tumor in nearly all cases. Infusing nanoparticles into the tissue around the tumor that target and kill these invading cancer cells could prevent reoccurance. We have found that larger nanoparticles that are infused into the brain tend to be transported along and accumulate in perivascular spaces, in the same location that invading tumor cells are frequently found. Thus using larger nanoparticles, even though they move less easily through the tissue, could lead to increased concentration of the therapeutic at exactly the spot where the invading cancer cells lie.
